On Tue, 4 Feb 2003, Scott Stirling wrote:

> I've been thinking about Test Driven Development and the question of
> what is it about it that ensures testability. As Kent Beck says, if
> you follow TDD religiously, you should have 100% statement coverage
> for your code. Let me repeat that: 100%.

Yes, Kent Beck indeed did say, "TDD followed religiously should result
in 100% statement coverage." But on the other hand, the sentence
before that in his TDD book is "Statement coverage is certainly not a
sufficient measure of test quality, but it is a starting place." If you
look at the chapter on method/class scope testing in Binder's _Testing
Object Oriented Systems_, you'll find that having meerly full statement
coverage is pretty poor test quality indeed. If you're looking just at a
coverage metric, I'd say you want at least full coverage of branches.

But then again, Kent Beck also said, on page 115/6 of _Extreme
Programming Explained_, "So you should write the tests that help get
programs working and keep programs working. Nothing more."

In the end, it really depends on the consequences of failure. In most
of the systems I build, the consequence of failure is a stack exception
appearing on the screen and a slightly troubled user. No big deal if
that happens once in a while; I just find, fix and roll out a new release.

On the other hand, if I had an embedded system that was going to be
mass-produced, where a new release is extremely expensive, I'd spend a
lot more money and time testing.

> I engaged in a stimulating debate with Curt on his answer, which I tried to
> argue wasn't as elegant or object oriented, in principle, as a mock object
> approach.  It won't result in 100% statement coverage, for one thing (which
> will require you to trust Curt or whomever that the 5% of code that isn't
> covered by unit tests, "can't go wrong," which might be true, but more
> likely not).

Actually, I see it as relying on my judgement that it's cheaper to deal
with the rare failures in that area when they happen than it is to spend
the money and time for more comprehensive test coverage.

> So why are we arguing such different strategies for solving
> the problem of "testability?"

Because we're costing it out differently. That's all.

> Put another way, I wonder the same thing about any behavior added to an
> object.  Testing is not a behavior of most objects.

Well, this perhaps a point of disagreement. I think that testing is a
potential behaviour of every object I write.

> It seems the best way to build and test a finite-state machine is
> to make the inputs and outputs explicit, and to make the state
> transitions step-wise and traceable.

I would consider that to be modifying an object, beyond its overt
function, to make it more testable.

If you didn't have to test the object, because you always wrote perfect
code, would you bother exposing the state-wide transitions?
